title.narrative: COVID-19 Oxfam-Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights Initiative
COVID-19 Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights, initiative

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Försvara och främja SRHR för flickor, kvinnor och transpersoner.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution Promoting Health and Sexual and Reproductive Rights of Maya, Garifuna and Mestizo Adult Women, Young Women, Adolescent Girls and Trans Women in Guatemala, implemented by Oxfam Intermón and eight local partner organizations, during a period of five years. The Swedish contribution to the project is SEK 76,5 million and Oxfam Intermon will contribute with approximately SEK 3,5 million. The objective of this project is to defend and promote the sexual and reproductive health and rights of girls, women and trans persons in 10 regions in Guatemala. Financially, the Swedish funds allocated to this contribution will be used for the carrying out of trainings on sexual and reproductive rights with girls and women; attention and the creation of platforms where organizations of women can meet and discuss common challenges and solutions; the provision of psychosocial care to survivors of sexual violence; to provide legal assistance and accompaniment in cases of sexual violence; and other activities. Additionally, the funds also target young men who have the potential to change the social imaginary and prevent violence against women. This will be achieved through training possesses and through working with young male leaders from grassroot organizations who will, in turn, be able to affect and provide training to other young men. The activities will be implemented by the eight partner organizations and are estimated to benefit a total of more than 62 000 persons, the majority of whom are women. In addition, the project includes advocacy and awareness raising in order to affect institutions and operators working with justice, health and education on SRHR.

The contribution Promoting Health and Sexual and Reproductive Rights of Maya, Garifuna and Mestizo Adult Women, Young Women, Adolescent Girls and Trans Women in Guatemala, implemented by Oxfam Intermón and eight local partner organizations, during a period of five years. The Swedish contribution to the project is SEK 76,5 million and Oxfam Intermon will contribute with approximately SEK 3,5 million. The objective of this project is to defend and promote the sexual and reproductive health and rights of girls, women and trans persons in 10 regions in Guatemala. Financially, the Swedish funds allocated to this contribution will be used for the carrying out of trainings on sexual and reproductive rights with girls and women; attention and the creation of platforms where organizations of women can meet and discuss common challenges and solutions; the provision of psychosocial care to survivors of sexual violence; to provide legal assistance and accompaniment in cases of sexual violence; and other activities. Additionally, the funds also target young men who have the potential to change the social imaginary and prevent violence against women. This will be achieved through training possesses and through working with young male leaders from grassroot organizations who will, in turn, be able to affect and provide training to other young men. The activities will be implemented by the eight partner organizations and are estimated to benefit a total of more than 62 000 persons, the majority of whom are women. In addition, the project includes advocacy and awareness raising in order to affect institutions and operators working with justice, health and education on SRHR.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
The agreement with Oxfam was signed in March 2019. This first period of implementation has gone into preparation of the training program, methodology and developing the strategy of the advocacy area. It is premature to report results, but some progress is listed below: In the area of training process, (i) Initiated the training program with technical and strategic assistance: 3,514 of girls and women are empowered on feminism, gender identity, sexual orientation, SRHR and GBV among others. (ii) 3,514 women and girls and trans are more empowered on their SRHR. (iii) The strategy of the training process implemented, allowed the strengthening of the knowledge and capacities of training teams of eight organizations member of the consortium. (iv) eight women organizations are in the processes of strengthening their technical and administrative capacities in order to focuses on the areas that require improvement. (v) A global training plan for 8 organizations was developed to homogenize the technical content of the training program. Additionally, the advocacy plan was also developed. The implementation is part of the work plan 2020. With reference to the objective 2, (i) 139 girls and women received psychological assistance. (ii) 418 women received medical assistance;( 87 are women trans; 136 adolescents and 195 women). (iii) the partner provided legal, psychological and medical support services to 23 persons (women and girls/adolescents victims and survivors of sexual violence). 12 of these 23 cases of sexual abuse were presented in the Court. Sida approved adjustments in accordance to a specific proposal and budget submitted by Oxfam Intermon, due to the Covid-19 situation in April 2020. The adjusted plan, budget and Minute are archived physically. These documents are considered as part of the annual plan and budget 2020. The amount of the adjustment is GTQ. 2,491,432.
Progress results during 2021
1. Despite of the pandemic, the progress of results turned out according to the work plan. As a result of the Covid-19 pandemic and the constant risk of infection from in person meetings, the organizations established new strategies and approaches to reach their target audiences, adapting their methodologies and techniques. These changes included procuring the necessary licenses and training facilitators to use technology solutions and lead virtual and remote meetings. A strategy was developed with the facilitators to identify participants that could be reached by the information technology tools to serve the target population for the program. In-person strategies were maintained for groups that faced a greater technology gap and had limited internet access. 2. In the area of training processes: (i) 549 women were involved in the training processes, allowing the participants to improve their knowledge of their bodies and sexual and reproductive rights. These trainings also supported participants decision-making on birth control methods, access to sexual and reproductive health services, and engagement with community groups. (ii) The awareness -raising process reached 17, 270 women, who learned about sexual and reproductive rights, prevention of sexual violence, and Covid prevention. This process was conducted through in-person formats and repeated with persons and social media or the radio system. (iii) 500 midwives were strengthened in their work, they received bio-security and personal protection equipment for their work on the front lines to serve women in times of Covid-19. This area of work had an important effect on pregnant women who were able to access maternal and infant health check-ups in their communities during the pandemic. 3. As part of the outcome social actors, community stakeholders and youth have transformed their social norms to be free from violence, sexism, and discrimination, the contribution reflects progress as follows: (i) 6,700 youth, teachers and community leaders have been strengthened and have gained awareness of the power relations that causes violence against women and girls and have questioned traditional forms of masculinity that normalize violence. Due to the pandemic, these actions have included social media outreach, radio broadcasts, streets festivals and online and community activities to change the mindset and social norms around sexual violence. (ii) Two communication campaigns were implemented in six Mayan language and in Spanish in the program intervention area, on issues of sexual and reproductive rights and reporting sexual violence. These campaigns were spread over the radio, social media and printed materials reaching over 235, 200 people. The campaign on reporting sexual violence was coordinated with the Secretariat Against Violence, Exploitation and Trafficking in persons, SVET, which is the advisory body for the State of Guatemala on matters of sexual violence, trafficking, and exploitation, to support the enforcement of the awareness-raising sections of Policy against Violence, Exploitation and Trafficking in persons.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
